awd_titl_txt: Alamo Institute for Materials (micro, bio, nano) - Technology (AIM-TEC)
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanotechnology is fundamentally changing the industrial world revolutionizing transportation, aerospace, biotechnology, medicine and manufacturing. The state of Texas has the fourth largest number of nanotechnology companies and institutions in the U.S. with over 66 nanotechnology-related companies and 50 nanoscience-related research and community organizations. The proposed Alamo Institute for Materials Technology (AIMTEC) project addresses the state's urgent workforce development needs in nanotechnology as identified by the Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board in its recent "Nanotechnology Forecast" report.

The Alamo Institute for Materials Technology (AIM-TEC) at Northwest Vista College will create a self-sustaining and replicable regional workforce model that leverages local resources and partnerships to address the critical need by industry for quality technician education and training in advanced materials technology. AIM-TEC will act as a regional hub for 1) supporting the educational preparation of next generation technicians with skills in micro-nano-bio technologies; 2) strengthening the transition points from high school to college, and college to workforce and/or advanced education through innovative student recruitment and retention strategies; 3) increasing community awareness of nanotechnology and available educational and career pathways. AIM-TEC will demonstrate effective ways that two-year institutions can creatively establish and lead an interconnected network of 7-12, 4-year institutions, NSF Centers, and industry partners to meet regional nanotechnology industry workforce needs. Through collaboration with national and regional educational and industry partners, AIM-TEC will establish micro-bio-nanotechnology curricula to produce graduates with industry-relevant technical competencies. A sixty-credit Associate of Applied Science (AAS) in Advanced Materials Technology embedded with two stackable Level-1 certificate options in Nano-biotechnology and Semiconductor technology will be developed. These curricular changes integrated with student experiential learning opportunities will diversify student skill sets, thereby creating multiple career pathways into nanotechnology-enabled industries. Additionally, AIM-TEC will pilot dual credit courses that will facilitate seamless transition of high school graduates to postsecondary educational institutions. The AIM-TEC project will increase the participation of underrepresented individuals in STEM fields by providing nanotechnology training, research opportunities and career development activities in a supportive environment at Northwest Vista College, a Hispanic-serving Institution.

por.por_cntn:
Outocme 1: AIM-TEC program has developed a strong alliance of educators, students, industry, and R&D organizations, across Texas and has successfully coordinated with local existing industries in materials and Nanotechnology fields including: Southwest Research Institute (SwRI), Tower Semiconductor Ltd, Micropower Global, the Materials Science Engineering and Commercialization Program at Texas State University, the Electrical Engineering Program at the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA), and the Department of Physics at UTSA, Department of Biomedical Engineering, at UTSA. These industry partners have offered internship training for AMT students. Also, scientists, lead manufacturing engineers, and faculties from these departments and companies are members of the AMT advisory board at NVC, which they advise on curriculum development and education training.

Outcome 2 During this grant, the best practice of AIM-TEC project was disseminated in the virtual MNT-EC summer seminar series, ATE PI conferences, (MNTeSIG) live conferences, and HI-TEC conferences.

Outcome 3. During the grant, the Nanotechnology and Engineering courses in the AMT program were updated and Engineering courses were added to the degree curriculum, with transferability to UTSA. 

Outcome 4: AIM-TEC has continued to provide multiple education and career pathways for the students to diversify their employment opportunities including: Southwest Research Institute (SwRI), Tower Semiconductor, MicroPower Global, UTSA, and Texas State University. During the AIM-TEC grant, Tower Semiconductor joined the internship program and offered full semester of cleanroom and wafer analysis training to AMT students.

Outcome 5: During all years of the grant, AIM-TEC has continued to leverage the existing collaboration with the local University to enhance the technical competencies of the graduates by offering microscopy hands-on training sessions at the Kleberg Advanced Microscopy Center at UTSA in each of spring and summer semesters. Also, Internship training at UTSA and Tower Semiconductor was offered to AMT students which up-graded the student skills to compete in Nanotechnology workforce. A total of 9 students spent internships at Soutwest Research Institute. 20 students complete microscopy trainings at UTSA. 5 students completed trainings at Tower Semiconductor. 

Outcome 6: During Fall 2017-Spring 2021, 63 students were enrolled in the Introductory Nanotechnology course from AMT program, Computer science and Engineering, and Biology majors. 

31 students were enrolled in the Nanoengineering/Nanobiotechnology AAS degree in Fall 2020-spring 2021.

61 students were enrolled in the Advanced Materials Technology program in the academic years of 2018-2021.

The number of graduates for the following academic years are as below:

2021-2020, 10 graduates

2020-2019, 6 graduates

2019-2018, 10 graduates

2018-2017, 5 graduates

Compared to the years prior to start date of the AIM-TEC grant, i.e., 2013-2016, the number of students enrolled in the program and number of graduates have been significantly increased. The number of graduates for these years, were 1-3 students per year, and an enrollment of 10-15 students per academic year.

Outcome 8: AIM-TEC public informational events successfully reached out to 150 community members during the grant period including middle school students, high school students, high school teachers, and college faculties. Outreach occurred during the nano and public events including: summer workshops and science fairs.

Outcome 9: During the grant, AIM-TEC hosted 3 summer nanotechnology workshops for high school students and high school educators. A total of 45 students and 45 educators participated in these workshops.


Last Modified: 09/16/2022
Modified by: Neda Habibi
